newsitem.title: USA: ATHLETICS-JOHNSON CONSIDERED FOR WILD CARD BERTH FOR WORLDS.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-JOHNSON CONSIDERED FOR WILD CARD BERTH FOR WORLDS.

text.p: Injured double Olympic champion Michael Johnson may get a second chance to compete in the world athletics championships this summer.

The executive committee of USA Track and Field will consider Thursday asking the International Amateur Athletic Federation (IAAF) for wild-card positions for Johnson and other injured American stars in the August world championships in Athens.
Under current U.S. qualifying rules, only athletes who finish in the top three at the U.S. championships are eligible for the American team for the world championships.

But IAAF officials, faced with the loss of Johnson and U.S. stars Dan O'Brien, Mike Powell and Gwen Torrence at the world championships, have indicated they are willing to consider "wild card" entries for defending world champions. That would include Johnson, O'Brien and Torrence.

Johnson, recovering from severely pulled left quadriceps suffered in his 150-meter showdown with 100-meter world record-holder Donovan Bailey, said Wednesday in Dallas he would consider such an invitation.
"I'm not going to lobby for it," said the 200-meter world record holder. "I don't think it is something I should do. If they ask me to compete, I'll consider it."
Johnson said he was "coming around slowly" from his injury. "There is still some swelling," he said.
He said he had been working out on an exercise bike since Monday and hoped to be back on the track training by next Monday.
He is still hopeful of making his first European appearance this season in a 400 meters in Paris on June 25.
